metadata.case_name: Seth Gulabchand v. Heirs and legal representatives of Seth Govindram Seksaria

facts.text: Govindram Seksaria, Brijlal Ramjidas, Bilasrai Joharmal and four other persons entered into a deed of partnership on July 17, 1935 for carrying on the business of acting as Managing Agents and Selling Agents of Indore Malwa United Mills Ltd.
Serious disputes arose between the partners.

Board of Directors of the Company appointed a Committee in November 1940 to enquire into certain allegations made against Govindram Seksaria, Brijlal and Bilasrai. The Committee consisted of Mr. R. C. Jall as Chairman, and Seth Hiralal and the plaintiff as members.
Partners referred their differences to the arbitration of Col. Dina Nath, the Prime Minister of the former Holkar State.

On February 8, 1941, the Arbitrator gave an award deciding that Govindram Seksaria should buy up the five-annas shares of Brijlal Ramjidas and Bilasrai Joharmal at par and that the latter should sell their respective shares of annas two and a half each in the rupee at par and also sell the debentures held by them to Govindram Seksaria at par.

On February 12, 1941, Brijlal and Bilasrai instituted a suit in the Bombay High Court against Govindram and other partners contesting the validity of the award made by Col. Dina Nath. They failed before the Bombay High Court and ultimately before the Privy Council.
After the award was made Govindram addressed a letter to Mr. Jall as a member of the Enquiry Committee on February 13, 1941, intimating the award and forwarding a copy.
On the same date Govindram addressed a similar letter to the plaintiff.

A day or two after the receipt of this letter by the plaintiff Govindram met him at his house and made him an offer of making him a partner of the managing agency firm by assigning two and half annas shares out of the share of Brijlal and Bilasrai which he was to get under the award.
The next day the plaintiff accepted the offer and on February 28, 1941, the agreement was concluded between the parties.

A day before the agreement was signed by the parties, Gulabchand, Plaintiff, addressed a letter to Mr. Jall, the Chairman of the Enquiry Committee, on February 27, 1941, for holding the meetings of the Committee daily so as to expedite its report.

On February 8, 1941, Govindram met Mr. Jall, and offered to sell to him one anna share, which he rejected saying that as he was the member of the Enquiry Committee, it would look as if he was making the offer to please him.
The Committee gave its final report on April 7, 1941, which was favourable to Govindram, although the interim report dated December 16, 1940, was not too favourable to him.
The plaintiff had no previous experience of the working of any Mill and had never been a managing agent of any textile mill.
Govindram was a rich man and a millionaire.
In 1942 Govindram suggested to the plaintiff that the share to be sold to him should be reduced to one and a half annas, but the plaintiff did not accept the suggestion.

Later, in 1942, when Mr. Jall questioned Govindram about the intended reduction in the share which was to be sold to the plaintiff, Govindram replied that he did not really intend to give any share to the plaintiff or anyone and that he proposed to give the entire four-annas share to the Holkar State by way of charity.
Govindram died in May 1946.
On November 5, 1947, a deed of assignment of the four-annas share of Brijlal and Bilasrai was executed in favour of the defendants as legal representatives of Govindram.
On November 6, 1947, the plaintiff instituted the suit for specific performance of the agreement dated February 28, 1941.
Sanghi, J., decreed the suit on June 11, 1948.

Defendants filed an appeal to a Division Bench of the Madhya Bharat High Court and the plaintiff preferred a cross appeal. The Division Bench accepted the defendants appeal, reversed the judgment and decree of Sanghi, J., and dismissed the plaintiffs suit as also his cross appeal.

Plaintiff filed an appeal under S. 25 of the Madhya Bharat High Court of Judicature Act, 1949. Full Bench held appeal incompetent, but Supreme Court held it competent and remitted for decision on merits.
On remand the Full Bench upheld the decision of the Division Bench and dismissed the appeal.

Issue No. 4: Was the agreement to sell the two and a half annas share a bribe offered by the deceased Seth Govindram to the plaintiff to write a report favourable to him, the plaintiff being a member of the Committee of three persons appointed by the Directors of the Malwa Mills, Indore to enquire into and report on the management of the Mills by Seth Govindram? Both Division Bench and Full Bench held this issue proved.
Balance-sheets showed that Govindram had earned enough money by way of selling and managing agency commission and it was not necessary for him to find a financial partner in the plaintiff.
Govindram continued to manage the Mill without the plaintiff, putting him off by saying that the contract would be fulfilled after the end of the litigation initiated by Bilasrai and Brijlal.
HiralaI had deposed that after the award the plaintiff saw him and told him that there was some settlement between him and Govindram.

legal_issues.text: Was the agreement to sell the two and a half annas share a bribe offered by the deceased Seth Govindram to the plaintiff to write a report favourable to him, the plaintiff being a member of the Committee?
What is the standard of proof required when bribery is alleged in a civil case?
Was there proof that the plaintiff was a party to the intention of Govindram to bribe him?
Does immorality within s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act confine to sexual immorality?

petitioner_arguments.text: There is no evidence in support of the findings arrived at by the Full Bench and that the findings are based on mere surmises.
Where bribery is alleged in a civil case the same standard of proof should be required as in a criminal matter, beyond reasonable doubt.
The High Court should have held that Hiralal's evidence was not admissible as what he stated was not put to the plaintiff.

There was no proof at all that the plaintiff was a party to the intention of Govindram to bribe him. There is presumption that the plaintiff acted honestly and no material has been placed to displace that presumption.
In case of circumstantial evidence the circumstances must be such as to exclude any other reasonable possibility.
Immorality within s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act is confined to sexual immorality.

respondent_arguments.text: Preliminary objection as to the competency of the appeal under S. 25 of the Madhya Bharat High Court of Judicature Act.
The agreement was a bribe offered by Govindram to the plaintiff.

court_reasoning.text: From all these facts the Division Bench inferred and concluded that the offer of two and a half annas share by Govindram to the plaintiff was a bribe in order to induce him to report in his favour and was accepted as such by Gulabchand. This conclusion was challenged before the Full Bench but upheld.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The transaction was in the nature of bribe to the plaintiff.

court_reasoning.text: The Full Bench found that Govindram did not care for the plaintiff's money or services, continued to manage without him, suggested reduction, told Jall he did not intend to give share. Ostensible reason too thin.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Balance-sheets showed no need for financial partner; prepared to give entire share to Holkar State in charity.

court_reasoning.text: The conclusion that the transaction was a bribe has all the commendation which common sense and realities give it. Legitimately drawn from facts proved and probabilities. Defendants discharged burden of proof; not required to prove beyond reasonable doubt as in criminal case.
No force in contention of no evidence or mere surmises; distinction between probability and surmise, but Full Bench did not rely on surmises.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Real complaint is treating as criminal case.

court_reasoning.text: Indian Evidence Act applies same standard of proof in all civil cases per s.3 definitions of proved, disproved, not proved. No difference for fraudulent/criminal charges. Presumption against crime kept in mind while striking balance of probability.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Woodroffe J. wrong in insisting on proof beyond reasonable doubt.

court_reasoning.text: Not necessary to decide admissibility of Hiralal's evidence as Full Bench did not base findings on it.
Unable to agree that for circumstantial evidence in civil fraud/bribery cases, must exclude any other reasonable possibility as in criminal cases. Ordinary civil rules apply.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fact judged on balance of probability.

court_reasoning.text: Not concerned with whether consideration immoral under s.23 Contract Act.

holdings.text: The offer of two and a half annas share was a bribe and accepted as such.
Standard of proof in civil cases alleging bribery is balance of probabilities under s.3 Evidence Act, not beyond reasonable doubt.
Circumstantial evidence in civil bribery does not require excluding every other reasonable possibility as in criminal cases.

precedents_cited.relevance: Woodroffe J. observations on proof beyond reasonable doubt in civil cases with criminal charges; court holds wrong.
Standard of proof in civil cases with criminal charges not same as criminal; prudent man standard under Evidence Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prasannamayi Debya v. Baikuntha Nath Chattoraj
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Jarat Kumari on standard of proof.
Meredith J. on circumstantial evidence excluding other possibilities; court disagrees for civil cases.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines proved, disproved, not proved; same standard in all civil cases, balance of probabilities.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Immorality of consideration; court not concerned as bribe issue sufficient.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Bharat High Court of Judicature Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Appeal competency previously decided by Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed as the concurrent finding that the agreement was a bribe stands, and no merit in appellant's contentions on evidence, standard of proof, or other points.

key_quotes.text: It is apparent from the above definitions that the Indian Evidence Act applies the same standard of proof in all civil cases. It makes no difference between cases in which charges of a fraudulent or criminal character are made and cases in which such charges are not made.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on standard of proof in civil bribery allegations.

key_quotes.text: The conclusion at which the learned Judges arrived that the transaction was in the nature of bribe to the plaintiff appears to us to have all the commendation which common sense and the realities of the case can give it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds finding of bribe based on probabilities.

key_quotes.text: where, whatever be the form of the proceeding, charges of a fraudulent or criminal character are made against a party thereto, it is right to insist that such charges be proved clearly and beyond reasonable doubt
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Quoted from Weston case; rejected by court.
